did.unittitle: D. Lyle Aten Papers

physdesc.extent: 4 legal document boxes, 1 slim letter document box, 3 shoe boxes, 3 flat boxes, 3 oversize folders

did.abstract: The D. Lyle Aten Papers (dated 1951-2013, undated; 3.69 cubic feet and 1.11 Gigabytes; 4 legal document boxes, 1 slim letter document box, 3 shoe boxes, 3 flat boxes, 3 oversize folders, and 439 digital images) primarily comprise digital and analog photographs and slides; as well as surveys, plans, and reports; brochures, newsletters, and other printed material; speeches and presentations; course syllabi and assignments; newspaper clippings; honors and awards; and architectural drawings that document the landscape architecture and urban design projects and university teaching carried out by landscape architect D. Lyle Aten and the landscape architecture firm Scruggs and Hammond, Inc., primarily in Lexington, Kentucky, and the Commonwealth of Kentucky from the mid-twentieth century to the early twenty-first century.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged by subject and format into 10 series: Biographical, Honors, Project Information, Subject Files, Teaching, Digital Photographs, Photographic Prints and Negatives, Photographic Slides, Photographs and Slides Information, and Drawings.

bioghist.head: Biographical
bioghist.p: Donovan Lyle Lyle Aten (1927-2017) was a landscape architect who practiced primarily in Kentucky, mainly in Fayette County. Aten was born on February 9, 1927, in Macomb, McDonough County, Illinois. His parents were Ferrol Glade Aten (1899-1975) and Mary Pauline Bryan Aten (1904-1993). He was mustered into the United States Navy as a seaman second class during World War II, and served as an electrician on board the U.S.S. Bairoko, 1945-1946. He attended Western Illinois University, 1947-1948, and graduated with a Bachelors of Fine Arts in Landscape Architecture from University of Illinois in 1951, supported by the Servicemen's Readjustment Act of 1944 (the G.I. Bill). One of his major professors at the University of Illinois was landscape architect Hideo Sasaki.

After graduating from college, Aten began working for the landscape architecture firm Scruggs and Hammond, Inc., in Peoria, Illinois. John Dudley Scruggs and Clarence E. Hammond established the firm in 1946, specializing in park and recreation planning, land use planning, and regional and urban planning. Their clients included federal, state, and local governments; regional, county, and city planning commissions; developers; and eleemosynary groups. The firm had branch offices in Lexington, Kentucky, and Columbus, Ohio. Aten moved to Lexington in 1952 to work out of that office and remained with Scruggs and Hammond for 49 years. During that time, he was promoted to Associate Partner (1954), Principal Partner (1971), Vice President (1972), and President (1974-1993). After formally retiring in 1993, he continued working on landscape architecture projects through 2000. As one of the first landscape architects and landscape architecture practices in Lexington and the Bluegrass region of central Kentucky during post-World War II urban and suburban expansion, Aten was involved with residential, commercial, and infrastructure development not only in Kentucky, but also in Ohio and West Virginia.

With Scruggs and Hammond, Inc., in Lexington and Fayette County, Ky., Aten worked on master planning and site design for neighborhood projects (Eastland, Cardinal Valley, Lansdowne, Stonewall, Merrick Place, Hamburg, Hartland, Beaumont, Wellesley Heights); shopping center projects (Lexington Green, Hamburg, Beaumont, Tates Creek Center, Lansdowne, Lansbrook, Palomar); parks (Jacobson Park, Lakeside Park and Golf Course, Phoenix Park, Shillito Park); corporate centers and research parks (IBM Recreation Complex, Ashland Oil Headquarters, Coldstream Research Park); stadiums (University of Kentucky Commonwealth Stadium, Lexington Legends baseball field); and the realignment of Main and Vine Streets downtown and the reconstruction of Paris Pike from Lexington to Paris, Ky. Aten was also involved with both master planning and detailed site design for a variety of Kentucky state parks (Barkley Lake State Park, Blue Heron Campground, Jenny Wiley State Park, Barren River State Park, Pine Mountain State Park, Lake Cumberland State Park, John James Audubon State Park, Buckhorn Lake State Park) and regional state parks (Breaks Interstate Park, Ky. and Va., and Big South Fork National Recreation Area, Ky. and Tenn.).

While working in private practice, Aten also taught at the University of Kentucky, serving as a Visiting Critic in the Department of Architecture in the College of Engineering (1961-1963) and then as an adjunct Instructor in the Department of Horticulture and Landscape Design in the College of Agriculture (1974-1999). After full retirement from active project management in 2000, Aten served for eight years as a member of the Lexington Fayette County Planning Commission (2000-2008).

A Certified Landscape Architect through the Council of Landscape Architectural Registration Boards (CLARB) and a registered landscape architect in Ohio, West Virginia, and Kentucky, Aten was a co-founder of the Kentucky chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architecture (ASLA KY) and served as Secretary-Treasurer (1978-1979), Vice President (1979-1980), and President (1980-1981), and Trustee (1985-1986). He became a member of the national ASLA in 1952 and was named a fellow of the association (FASLA) in 1986. Aten's civic and community service roles in Lexington, Ky., included President, Citizens Association for Planning; charter member, Metro Environmental Improvement Commission; member, Mayor's Citizen Advisory Commission on Recommendations for the Planning and Zoning Process for Fayette County (1974); and member, Board of Trustees for Cardinal Hill Hospital (1978-1983);

Throughout his career, Aten received many awards for his landscape architecture work, including a merit award and an outstanding service award from the American Society of Landscape Architects (ASLA, 1974, 1986); five honor and special recognition awards and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Kentucky Chapter of ASLA (1982-1986, 2016); four honor and merit awards from the Kentucky Society of Architects (1972-1973); three awards from the Metro Environmental Improvement Commission (1970-1974); two awards from the Kentucky Department of Local Government Design (1985); and the Fayette County Outstanding Environmentalist Award (1976).

A long-distance runner, baseball player, painter, and singer, Aten was a member of and sang in the choir of the Second Presbyterian Church in Lexington, Ky. He was married to Mary Louise Swearington Aten (1929-2007) and Joy Molino Aten (1930- ) and had two daughters, Kathy Aten Birkebak and Susan Aten Borst; a step-son, Dan Molino; and a step-daughter-in-law, Sheila Molino. He died in Lexington, Ky., on July 30, 2017.
Sources:
1. 2013ms0843 : D. Lyle Aten papers, 1951-2013, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.
3. Donovan Lyle Aten, University of Kentucky Board of Trustees meeting minutes index cards, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

4. Eblen, Tom, Landscape architect Lyle Aten's many designs decorate Lexington, Lexington Herald-Leader, September 23, 2013. https://www.kentucky.com/news/business/article44445150.html. Accessed 6/25/2024.

5. KHC Member Profile: American Society of Landscape Architects (ASLA)--KY, Kentucky Horticulture Council. https://kyhortcouncil.org/2022/10/02/khc-member-profile-american-society-of-landscape-architects-asla-ky//. Accessed 6/25/2024.
6. Lifetime Achievement Award: Lyle Aten, Broken Sidewalk. https://brokensidewalk.com/2016/ky-asla-awards/. Accessed 6/25/2024.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 2013ms0843 : [identification of item], D. Lyle Aten Papers, 1951-2013, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The D. Lyle Aten Papers (dated 1951-2013, undated; 3.69 cubic feet and 1.11 Gigabytes; 4 legal document boxes, 1 slim letter document box, 3 shoe boxes, 3 flat boxes, 3 oversize folders, and 439 digital images) primarily comprise digital and analog photographs and slides; as well as surveys, plans, and reports; brochures, newsletters, and other printed material; speeches and presentations; course syllabi and assignments; newspaper clippings; honors and awards; and architectural drawings that document the landscape architecture and urban design projects and university teaching carried out by landscape architect D. Lyle Aten and the landscape architecture firm Scruggs and Hammond, Inc., primarily in Lexington, Kentucky, and the Commonwealth of Kentucky from the mid-twentieth century to the early twenty-first century. The projects Aten and Scruggs and Hammond worked on include state and city parks, residential subdivisions, shopping centers, roadways and corridors, and industrial facilities. Specific locations and buildings represented in the collection through images or through site master plans, reports, and newspaper clippings include the Ashland Oil Building, Lexington, Kentucky (1978-1985) and Ashland Corporate Headquarters, Ashland, Ky. (1985-1987); Blue Heron Campground, South Fork, Kentucky (1988-1994); Columbia, Maryland (1972); Council of State Governments building and Spindletop estate, Fayette County, Kentucky (1971-1989); Equestrian Woods, Nicholasville, Ky. (1989 and undated); Idle Hour subdivision and Idle Hour Country Club, Lexington, Ky., (undated); Paris Pike, Fayette County and Bourbon County, Ky. (1966-1995); the Oaks condominiums, Lexington, Ky. (undated); and Vine Street and downtown, Lexington, Ky. (1971-1986 and undated). There are very few architectural and landscape drawings. The collection also includes Scruggs and Hammond booklets (1970), newsletters and newspaper clippings (1980-1996), and an urban renewal projects photograph album (1960) as well as Lexington, Ky., and Fayette County, Ky. urban redevelopment plans and reports from 1993 to 2011.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Donovan Lyle Aten Oral History Project (dla), Louie B. Nunn Center for Oral History, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center. https://kentuckyoralhistory.org/ark:/16417/xt79cn6z049b

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing of the D. Lyle Aten Papers was generously supported by Joy Aten in memory of Lyle Aten.

did.unittitle: Biographical

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Biographical series (1951-2013, undated) comprises college school work, event programs, letters, resumes, and speech notes related to D. Lyle Aten's academic and professional work as a landscape architect. The series also contains newspaper clippings about Aten and two ink jet printed photographs of Aten at school and a marathon. The series is arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is of a personal and professional nature and includes compliments to Aten about his development as a landscape architecture student. Sasaki hopes to get all of Aten's class of landscape design students to attend the graduate school at Harvard University and is offering financial support. Folder includes a semester evaluation grade sheet for Aten by Sasaki.

Honors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Honors series (1973-2008, undated) comprises certificates for awards D. Lyle Aten received from the American Society of Landscape Architects, the Kentucky Chapter of the American Society for Landscape Architects, and the Lexington-Fayette Urban County Government. Also included is a certification to practice in West Virginia and commendation letters from other professional architects and planners. The series is arranged alphabetically by title.

Project Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Project Information series (1962-2013, undated) comprises brochures, data sheets, and plans of landscape architecture projects worked on by D. Lyle Aten. Notable projects include the Coldstream Research Campus for the University of Kentucky; Phoenix Park in downtown Lexington, Kentucky; Lake Barkley Kentucky State Park; and Riverfront Park in Bowling Green, Kentucky. The series is arranged into subseries by project categories and thereunder alphabetically by project title.

Subject Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Subject Files series (1951-2011, undated) comprises reports, handbooks, and newspaper clippings about Lexington, Ky., and Bluegrass region planning projects, as well as publications by and documents related to Scruggs and Hammond, Inc., landscape architecture firm. The series is arranged into subseries by subject and thereunder alphabetically by title.

Teaching

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Teaching series (1968-1994) comprises course information for classes taught by D. Lyle Aten at the University of Kentucky School of Architecture and as a lecturer at University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. The series also includes a land use plan project designed by fifth-year University of Kentucky Architecture students on downtown Bowling Green, Kentucky, and an assignment problem for one of Aten's architecture classes. The series is arranged in alphabetical order by title of class or educational unit.

Digital Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Digital Photographs series (2009-2013) primarily comprise images in JPG format taken by Joy and Lyle Aten in 2013 to record Lyle Aten's landscape design projects in Lexington, Ky. Some personal and family images (2009-2013) are included, as well as photographs of Aten's residence, 448 Linwal road in Lexington, Ky. Projects and locations include Coldstream Park, Lexington, Ky.; Lexington Green shopping center, Lexington, Ky.; and Whitaker Bank Ballpark (Legends Ballpark), Lexington, Ky. Arranged in alphabetical order by location name.

Photographic Prints and Negatives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographic Prints and Negatives series (1970-2001, undated) include architecture and urban design projects, buildings, and locations Lyle Aten worked on or was interested in, primarily around Lexington, Kentucky. The types of projects include state, city, and county parks; horse farms; subdivisions; shopping centers; roadways and corridors; as well as industrial facilities. Specific projects, buildings, and locations represented include the Ashland Oil corporate offices, Ashland, Ky. (1985-1987); Idle Hour neighborhood and country club, Lexington, Ky. (undated); Paris Pike, Fayette County and Bourbon County, Ky. (undated); and the Oaks condominiums, Lexington, Ky. (undated). Arranged in alphabetical order by location name. Some of the locations were given a number (indicated in parentheses) and the numbers are included in the location title.

Photographic Slides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographic Slides series (1960 May-1995, undated) include various landscape architecture and urban design projects, buildings, and locations Lyle Aten worked on or was interested in, primarily around Lexington, Kentucky. The types of projects include state, city, and county parks; horse farms; subdivisions; shopping centers; roadways and corridors; as well as industrial facilities. Specific projects, buildings, and locations represented include Ashland Oil Building, Lexington, Kentucky (1978-1985); Blue Heron Campground, South Fork, Kentucky (1988-1994); Columbia, Maryland (1972); Council of State Governments building and Spindletop estate, Fayette County, Kentucky (1971-1989); Equestrian Woods, Nicholasville, Ky. (1989 and undated); Idle Hour, Lexington, Ky., (undated); Jenny Wiley State Park, Ky. (1966-1986 and undated); Kentucky Dam Village State Resort Park and Kentucky Lake (1962-1963); Lakeside Golf Course, Lexington, Ky. (1971); Nicollet Mall, Minneapolis, Minn. (1969); Paris Pike, Fayette County and Bourbon County, Ky. (1966-1995); Town Branch, Lexington, Ky. (1970-1971); various University of Kentucky farms and landscapes (1970-1977); Vine Street and downtown, Lexington, Ky. (1971-1986 and undated).

Also included are slides of Lexington and regional locations and buildings used by Aten for teaching landscape architecture courses at the University of Kentucky. Specific locations and buildings represented include Gainesway Park, Lexington, Kentucky (1983); Minoru Yamasaki buildings at Wayne State University, Detroit, Michigan (1962); Pipestem Resort State Park, Pipestem, West Virginia (1974); Transylvania College, Lexington, Ky. (1967-1973); Wolf Run Park, Lexington, Kentucky (1971); and aerial photographs of various subdivisions in Lexington, Ky. (1967-1970). Where possible, the archivist retained Aten's slide titles. When received, the slides had been organized into two groups: Projects and Teaching. These groups have been retained as subseries within the photographic slides series. Numbers in parentheses indicate the number of slides present for each location.

Photographs and Slides Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographs and Slides Information series (undated) includes handwritten information that accompanied the photographic prints and slides when they were received by the Special Collections Research Center. Arranged in alphabetical order by title.

did.unittitle: Original list of prints and slides and original slide labels
List of teaching slides
Drawings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Drawings series (1955-1982, undated) primarily comprises architectural drawings of three residential projects Aten designed or co-designed, including for Dr. and Mrs. Bruce J. Morrow in Macomb, Illinois, 1955-1957. There are also architectural drawings in support of teaching or for a state park and a Fayette County and Bourbon County roadway. Arranged into two subseries by type of project and thereunder alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.p: Includes landscape plan; master construction plan; carport details; screened porch, deck, and construction details.
